Starting off, I see two API methods right away.

-          A method that copies files:  copyFile(File source, File
destination) - void

-          A method that generates a File destination from a source:
createDestinationFile(File source) - File

From there I see the source is a common object, and maybe it should be a
part of the object doing the work.  Furthermore, I see them as being
package protected and not exposed (I'd like private, but I hate having
inner test classes).  Then I think to myself, if they are package
protected, what should the main function of the object be.  I then come
up with the high level API...

-          PhotoDirectoryRandomizer(File sourceDir, File destinationDir)

-          PhotoDirectoryRandomizer::copy() - void

 

Note: I would, and feel I should, do this before writing any tests.
This does not mean that I started writing any code.  I'm just realizing
what the API might need to be.  It appears that you started writing
tests before realizing the API.   I used to do that too, and found
myself throwing out a lot of my original tests.

 

The set of four methods (one being a constructor) is easy to test, and
easy to drive with a tool like JSAP (Which I swear on for a Java command
line parser).  The constructor would do "no work" but just object
initialization.  Finally the package protected methods can be tested
independently as that is where most of the work occurs.

 

I would not break it up past that.

 

Just my 0.02$.

 

Big Mike

 

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
rejohnsoca
Sent: Tuesday, August 25, 2009 3:32 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] What should I be testing?

 

  

I've been playing a bit with Test Driven Development, and have read the
book, but now I want to try it out, and am really not sure what to do
next...

My wife loves to show photo slide shows on our living room windows-XP
computer (have patience, it will come together), but she doesn't like
that the pictures show up in order. I want to write a small utility to
rename the pictures in a controllable way, but prefixing something like 
"RND", a set of random digits, and the original name. For example, if
the original was DCIM1001.jpg, I want the class to rename the file to
"RND4356332_DCIM1001.jpg". Windows can then show the photos in a
'random' order, but I can still figure out the real photo name, in case
someone wants a copy. Sounds simple.

I want to build this, using TDD.
I figure that I need to build tests, and get green bars in eclipse in
the following order:
-instantiate my photoRandomizer class
-pass it several different paths, and have them be validated (null,
empty, non-existing, very long, very short, etc...).

that was easy.
but my next question, is now what?
If I was writing this without TDD, my next step, would have been to
iterate through the directory, and rename all of the files according to
my scheme. I can't see an operational advantage to exposing any of this
to outside, or make it more than one method, for testing purposes.

maybe what I should do, is have a method that iterates through the
appropriate directory, generates a random number, and then passes both
pieces of information to another method which renames the target file.
This doesn't seem like a very good way to do it, but then I would at
least be able to test the renaming.

What am I missing?
